{{Infobox horseraces |class = Horse |horse race = 1200 Guineas Stakes |image = |caption = |location = [[Newmarket Racecourse]]
[[Newmarket, Suffolk|Newmarket]], [[England]] |inaugurated = 1757 |race type = [[Flat racing|Flat]] / [[Thoroughbred]] |distance = 3 miles 6½ furlongs |surface = Turf |track = |qualification = Five-year-olds |weight = 9 [[Stone (unit)|st]] (57 kg) |purse = }} The '''1200 Guineas Stakes''' was a [[Flat racing|flat]] [[Horse racing|horse race]] in [[Great Britain]] open to [[thoroughbred]]s aged five years. It was run at [[Newmarket Racecourse|Newmarket]] and was one of the most important races of the second half of the 18th century. ==History== The 1200 Guineas was established in 1753 to be first run during [[Easter]] week of 1757. It was established by the [[Prince William, Duke of Cumberland|Duke of Cumberland]], [[Peregrine Bertie, 3rd Duke of Ancaster and Kesteven|3rd Duke of Ancaster]], [[Charles Spencer, 3rd Duke of Marlborough|3rd Duke of Marlborough]], [[Charles Watson-Wentworth, 2nd Marquess of Rockingham|2nd Marquess of Rockingham]], [[William Cavendish, 4th Duke of Devonshire|Marquess of Hartington]], [[John Manners, Marquess of Granby|Marquess of Granby]], [[Francis Godolphin, 2nd Earl of Godolphin|2nd Earl of Godolphin]], [[Hugh Percy, 1st Duke of Northumberland|2nd Earl of Northumberland]], [[Alexander Montgomerie, 10th Earl of Eglinton|10th Earl of Eglinton]], [[Charles Lennox, 3rd Duke of Richmond|3rd Duke of Richmond]], [[John Leveson-Gower, 1st Earl Gower|1st Earl of Gower]] and Thomas Duncombe. They agreed the race was to be run over the Beacon course at [[Newmarket Racecourse|Newmarket]] and would be open to five-year-old horses and mares. They paid a 100 [[Guinea (British coin)|guineas]] subscription each to enter their horse and all runners would carry nine [[Stone (unit)|stone]].{{cite book |last1=Pick |first1=William |last2=Johnson |first2=R. |title=The Turf Register (Vol. I) |publisher=A. Bartholoman, High-Ousegate |year=1803}} The race was initially to be run for five consecutive years from 1757, but was subsequently renewed in 1762. ==Records to 1786== '''Leading owner (4 wins):''' * [[Richard Grosvenor, 1st Earl Grosvenor|1st Baron Grosvenor]] – ''Cadet (1762), Ancient Pistol (1769), Bay Halkin (1770), Pigeon (1774)'' ==Winners to 1786== {| class = "sortable" | border="1" cellpadding="0" style="border-collapse: collapse; font-size:90%" |- bgcolor="#77dd77" align="center" | width="45px" | '''Year'''
| width="150px" | '''Winner'''
| width="170px" | '''Owner'''

{{Use British English|date=February 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2015}} {{Infobox cricket tournament | previous_year = 1728 | previous_tournament = 1728 English cricket season | next_year = 1730 | next_tournament = 1730 English cricket season }} 1729 was the 33rd English [[cricket]] season since the earliest known [[First-class cricket#Important matches classification|important match]] was played. Details have survived of seven [[First-class cricket#Important matches classification|important matches]]. The earliest known [[innings]] victory is believed to have happened and the earliest known surviving [[cricket bat]] dates from the season. The earliest known reference to cricket in the county of [[Gloucestershire]] has been found.
== Important matches == The following matches are classified as [[First-class cricket#Important matches classification|important]]:<ref name="status" group="fc">First-class cricket was officially defined in May 1894 by a meeting at [[Lord's]] of [[Marylebone Cricket Club]] (MCC) and the [[county cricket|county clubs]] which were then competing in the [[County Championship]]. The ruling was effective from the beginning of the 1895 season. Pre-1895 matches of the same standard have no official definition of status because the ruling is not retrospective and the [[First-class cricket#Important matches classification|important matches]] designation, as applied to a given match, is based on the views of one or more substantial historical sources. For further information, see [[First-class cricket]], [[Forms of cricket]] and [[History of cricket]].</ref>
{| border="1" cellpadding="5" cellspacing="0" |- bgcolor="#efefef" ! width="10.0%" align="right" | date ! width="35.0%" align="left" | match title ! width="25.0%" align="left" | venue ! width="27.5%" align="left" | result ! width="2.50%" align="right" | source |- | align="right" | 24 June (Tu) | [[Kent county cricket teams|Kent]] v [[Sussex county cricket teams|Sussex]] | [[Walworth Common]] | result unknown | align="right" | <ref name=M38/> |- | align="right" | ''notes'' | colspan="4" | The match was for fifty pounds per side with a play or pay rule agreed. It is the earliest match featuring a team that is expressly called [[Sussex county cricket teams|Sussex]], though teams raised by patrons in earlier seasons are understood to have been composed mainly of Sussex players. |- | colspan="5" | |- | align="right" | 30 July (Wed) | [[Dartford Cricket Club|Dartford]] v [[London Cricket Club|London]] | [[Dartford Brent|Dartford]] (precise venue not specified) | result unknown | align="right" | <ref>Maun, pp. 38–39.</ref> |- | align="right" | ''notes'' | colspan="4" | The teams were described as "the Gentlemen of Dartford and London"; the stake was fifty pounds. |- | colspan="5" | |- | align="right" | 5 August (Tu) | [[London Cricket Club|London]] v [[Dartford Cricket Club|Dartford]] | [[Kennington Common]] | Dartford won "very much" | align="right" | <ref name=GB3>Buckley, p. 3.</ref><ref name=ACS19>ACS, ''Important Matches'', p. 19.</ref> |- | align="right" | ''notes'' | colspan="4" | Described thus: "a great Cricket Match at Kennington Common between the Londoners and the Dartford men, for a considerable Sum of Money, Wager and Betts, and the latter beat the former very much".<ref name=M39>Maun, p. 39.</ref> |- | colspan="5" | |- | align="right" | 26 August (Tu) | [[Surrey county cricket teams|Surrey]] v [[Kent county cricket teams|Kent]] | [[Holt Pound|Farnham]] (precise venue not specified) | result unknown | align="right" | <ref name=M39/> |- | align="right" | ''notes'' | colspan="4" | The ''Daily Journal'' on 26 August reported that a match would be played same day near Farnham between "[[Edwin Stead|Mr Steed]] (''sic'') of Kent and his Company, against the best Players in the County of Surrey".<ref name=M39/> |- | colspan="5" | |- | align="right" | 28 August (Th) | [[Edwin Stead's XI cricket team|Edwin Stead's XI]] v [[Sir William Gage's XI cricket team|Sir William Gage's XI]] | [[Penshurst Park]] | Sir William Gage's XI won (by an innings?) | align="right" | <ref name=DC>Waghorn, p. 7.</ref><ref>Wilson, p. 50.</ref><ref name=ACS19/> |- | align="right" | ''notes'' | colspan="4" | Stead v Gage was alternatively titled [[Kent county cricket teams|Kent]] (Stead's XI) v [[Sussex, Surrey & Hampshire cricket team|Sussex, Surrey & Hampshire]] (Gage's XI). It was an 11-a-side match played for 100 guineas with "some thousands" watching.<ref name=DC/> The match seems to have resulted in the earliest known [[innings]] victory as Gage's XI "got (within three) in one hand, as the former did in two hands, so the Kentish men (i.e., Stead's XI) threw it up". The report added re [[Thomas Waymark]] that "a groom of the [[Charles Lennox, 2nd Duke of Richmond|2nd Duke of Richmond]] signalised himself by extraordinary agility and dexterity".<ref name=DC/>
The report then states that "(Waymark) turned the scale of victory, which for some years past has been generally on the Kentish side".<ref name=DC/> This indicates that inter-county matches had been played for many years previously and that there was keen rivalry with each team seeking ascendancy: i.e., as "champions" or, given a 1728 reference to the superiority of Kent, at least of "bragging rights".<ref name=LL/>
Penshurst Park surrounds [[Penshurst Place]], then the seat of [[John Sidney, 6th Earl of Leicester]], near [[Tonbridge]] in [[Kent]]. |- | colspan="5" | |- | align="right" | ? Sept | [[Hampshire, Surrey & Sussex cricket team|Hampshire, Surrey & Sussex]] v [[Kent county cricket teams|Kent]] | [[The Dripping Pan|Lewes]] (precise venue not specified) | result unknown | align="right" | <ref name=DC/><ref name=ACS19/> |- | align="right" | ''notes'' | colspan="4" | A report dated 13 September says that: "the great match played at Penshurst will be played again in Sussex".<ref name=DC/> This is the first time that Hampshire is known to be used in a team name, though not individually.<ref name=LL>{{cite web|url=http://www.jl.sl.btinternet.co.uk/stampsite/cricket/ladstolords/1701.html#1729 |title=From Lads to Lord's – 1729 |last=Leach |first=John |publisher=Stumpsite |date=2007 |accessdate=28 February 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121010153249/http://www.jl.sl.btinternet.co.uk/stampsite/cricket/ladstolords/1701.html#1729 |archivedate=10 October 2012 }}</ref> |- |}
==County cricket== It appears that Gage's XI was representative of three counties and so should perhaps be considered a [[Non-international England cricket teams|Rest of England team]] formed to challenge Kent, who had hitherto enjoyed: "the scale of victory, which for some years past has been generally on the Kentish side" (see above). The match on 24 June involved a team specifically named Sussex, but the result is unknown. Despite losing to Gage's team in August, Kent under the patronage of Edwin Stead is generally believed to have been the strongest county team<ref name="champs" group="fc">"Champion County" is an unofficial seasonal title proclaimed by media or historians prior to December 1889 when the official [[County Championship]] was constituted.</ref> of the 1720s.<ref name=CC>{{cite web|url=http://www.jl.sl.btinternet.co.uk/stampsite/cricket/histories/champions.html |title=Champion cricket teams since 1728 |last=Leach |first=John |publisher=Stumpsite |date=2008 |accessdate=28 February 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080829042341/http://www.jl.sl.btinternet.co.uk/stampsite/cricket/histories/champions.html |archivedate=29 August 2008 }}</ref>
==Other events== [[File:Oldest cricket bat.JPG|right|thumb|250px|The oldest [[cricket]] [[cricket bat|bat]] still in existence dates from 1729. Note the shape, which is more like that of a modern-day hockey stick than a modern-day cricket bat. It is kept in the Sandham Room in the Member's Pavilion at [[the Oval]]]]
There is a bat in [[The Oval]] pavilion which belonged to John Chitty of [[Knaphill]], [[Surrey]]. Dated 1729, it is the oldest known bat.<ref name=RB>Bowen, p. 263.</ref> It looks more like a [[field hockey]] stick than a modern cricket bat but its curvature was to enable the batsman to play a ball that was always rolled or skimmed along the ground, as in [[bowls]], never pitched. Pitching began about 30 years later and the straight bats used nowadays were invented in response to the [[pitched delivery bowling|pitched delivery]].<ref name=LL/>
Dr [[Samuel Johnson]] attended the [[University of Oxford]] from October 1728 until the following summer and later told [[James Boswell]] that cricket matches were played there. Boswell mentioned this in his ''Life of Samuel Johnson''.<ref name=M38>Maun, p. 38.</ref>
''Tuesday, 5 August''. [[Gentlemen of Middlesex cricket team|Gentlemen of Middlesex]] v [[Gentlemen of London cricket team|Gentlemen of London]] was announced, to be played at the [[The "Woolpack" cricket ground, Islington|"Woolpack", Islington]]. The venue was described as "in the Field behind the ''Woolpack'' Back Gate near [[Sadler's Wells]]", the match having a stake of £50 per side. Several sources have listed the match in 1728 due to an error in original research. As London were playing Dartford on the same day (see above), this match was as advertised "gentlemen only".<ref name=DC/><ref name=LL/>
A local game in [[Gloucester]] on Monday, 22 September is the earliest known reference to cricket in [[Gloucestershire]].<ref name=RB/>
==First mentions== ===Counties=== * [[Gloucestershire]]<ref name=RB/>
===Clubs and teams=== * [[Gentlemen of London cricket team|Gentlemen of London]]<ref name=DC/> * [[Gentlemen of Middlesex cricket team|Gentlemen of Middlesex]]<ref name=DC/> * [[Hampshire, Surrey & Sussex cricket team|Hampshire, Surrey & Sussex]]<ref name=M38/> * [[Sussex county cricket teams|Sussex]]<ref name=M38/>
===Players=== * ''none'' ===Venues=== * [[Walworth Common]]<ref name=M38/> * [[The "Woolpack" cricket ground, Islington|"Woolpack", Islington]]<ref name=DC/> * [[Holt Pound|Farnham]]<ref name=M39/>

Women|Juventus]]
[[Fiorentina Women's F.C.|Fiorentina]] | league topscorer = [[Valentina Giacinti]]
(21 goals) | matches = 132 | total goals = 424 | prevseason = [[2016–17 Serie A (women)|2016–17]] | nextseason = [[2018–19 Serie A (women)|2018–19]] }} The '''2017–18 [[Serie A (women's football)|Serie A (women)]]''' was the 51st season of the women's football top level league in Italy. [[Fiorentina Women's F.C.|Fiorentina]] were the defending champions. [[Juventus F.C. Women|Juventus]] won the league title in their first ever season. ==Teams== Twelve teams will compete in the league, with many changes among the make up of the league compared to last season. Four teams were relegated at the end of the [[2016-17 Serie A (women)|2016-17]] season. [[E.D.P. Jesina|Jesina]], [[U.S.D. Luserna Calcio|Luserna]] and [[A.S.D. Femminile Chieti|Chieti]] finished at the bottom of the league, with [[F.C.F. Como 2000|Como 2000]] losing a relegation playoff to [[U.S. San Zaccaria|San Zaccaria]]. [[A.S.D. Reggiana Calcio Femminile|Reggiana]] won promotion from Serie B, but their license was taken over by [[A.S.D. Sassuolo Calcio Femminile|Sassuolo]].{{cite news|url=http://gazzettadireggio.gelocal.it/sport/2016/09/30/news/il-sassuolo-si-compra-la-reggiana-1.14178416|title=Il Sassuolo si compra la Reggiana|date=30 September 2016|access-date=6 October 2017|work=Gazzetta di Reggio|publisher=Gruppo Editoriale L'Espresso|location=Reggio Emilia|language=Italian}}{{cite press release|url=http://www.figcreggioemilia.it/upload/Comunicati/1045/CU46.pdf|title=Comunicato Ufficiale N°46 (2016–17)|date=31 May 2017|access-date=6 October 2017|work=Delegazione Provinciale di Reggio Emilia|publisher=FIGC|language=Italian}} Other promoted teams were [[Empoli Ladies F.C.|Empoli]], [[A.S.D. Fimauto Valpolicella|Valpolicella]] and [[A.S.D. Pink Sport Time|Pink Bari]]. [[A.S.D. Cuneo Calcio Femminile|Cuneo]], who finished seventh in Serie A last season, sold their license to [[Juventus F.C. Women|Juventus]].http://www.lastampa.it/2017/07/01/edizioni/cuneo/sport/ufficiale-alla-juve-i-diritti-del-cuneo-femminile-bxkPl1aazITJxFPd6QMAVI/pagina.html ==League table== Brescia gave their Serie A spot to [[AC Milan]] after the season, who created a women's team. They were not allowed to enter the Champions League therefore. {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2012}} {{Infobox organization | name = Association of Summer Olympic International Federations | native_name = | native_name_lang = | named_after = | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | logo = | logo_size = | logo_alt = | logo_caption = | map = | map_size = | map_alt = | map_caption = | map2 = | map2_size = | map2_alt = | map2_caption = | abbreviation = ASOIF | motto = | predecessor = | merged = | successor = | formation = {{start date and age|1983|05|30|df=yes}} | founder = | founding_location = | extinction = <!-- use {{end date and age|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | merger = | type = [[Nonprofit]] | tax_id = <!-- or | vat_id = (for European organizations) --> | registration_id = <!-- for non-profit org --> | status = | purpose = Inter-sport federation organisation | headquarters = [[Lausanne]] | location = | coords = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LON|display=inline, title}} --> | region = | services = | products = | methods = | fields = | membership = | membership_year = | language = | owner = <!-- or | owners = --> | sec_gen = | leader_title = President | leader_name = [[Francesco Ricci Bitti]] | leader_title2 = Vice President | leader_name2 = [[Wu Ching-kuo]] | leader_title3 = Executive Director | leader_name3 = Andrew Ryan | leader_title4 = | leader_name4 = | board_of_directors = | key_people = | main_organ = | parent_organization = | subsidiaries = | secessions = | affiliations = | budget = | budget_year = | revenue = | revenue_year = | disbursements = | expenses = | expenses_year = | endowment = | endowment_year = | staff = | staff_year = | volunteers = | volunteers_year = | slogan = | mission = | website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> | remarks = | formerly = | footnotes = }} The '''Association of Summer Olympic International Federations''' ('''ASOIF''') is a non-profit association of [[List of international sports federations|international sports federations]] that compete in the [[Summer Olympic Games]]. It is headquartered in [[Lausanne]], [[Switzerland]], the same city where the [[International Olympic Committee]] (IOC) is also headquartered.
==ASOIF Council== The Council is composed of a President and six Members, all from different Federations. One of the six Members is elected as Vice-President. The President and all the Members are elected for 4- year mandates. The Executive Director is nominated by the Council on the proposal of the President as an executive position. The Executive Director is also on the Council, but without voting rights.

== History ==
On 30 May 1983, the 21 International Federations governing the sports included at the time on the programme of the 1984 Summer Olympic Games decided to form the Association of Summer Olympic International Federations (ASOIF).
ASOIF was formed, as stated in the first article of its constitution 'to co-ordinate and to defend the common interests of its members' and to 'ensure close co-operation between its members, and members of the Olympic Movement and other organisations'. These needs were identified in order to preserve the unity of the Olympic movement while maintaining 'the authority, independence and autonomy of the member International Federations.'
The members of ASOIF meet once a year in a General Assembly. The General Assembly usually precedes the joint meeting between the Executive Board of the International Olympic Committee and the International Federations where a multitude of topics are discussed in the common interests of the Olympic Movement.
In 2015, the Organising Committee for the Olympic Games Tokyo 2020 had proposed five new sports in response to the new flexibility provided by Olympic Agenda 2020, the IOC’s strategic roadmap for the future of the Olympic Movement. Olympic Agenda 2020 gives host cities the option of suggesting new sports and events for inclusion in their edition of the Games. Karate, skateboarding, sports climbing, surfing and baseball/softball will be added to the Olympic Programme in Tokyo 2020. ASOIF has amended its statutes to enable IFs “governing sports included within the events programme for a specific edition of the Summer Olympic Games” to become “Associate Members”.
ASOIF is administered by an executive body, the Council, which consists of seven individual members, most of which are presidents of Summer Olympic International Federations.
The ASOIF General Secretariat is located in Lausanne and is administered by the ASOIF Executive Director.
==See also== * [[International Olympic Committee]] (IOC) * [[Association of International Olympic Winter Sports Federations]] (AIOWF) * [[Association of the IOC Recognised International Sports Federations]] (ARISF) * [[SportAccord]]

{{Contradict-other|KSV Ice Tigers|there|Austrian National League|date=December 2013}} {{Infobox sports league | logo = | pixels = | caption = Erste Bank Eishockey Liga | current_season = | sport = [[Ice hockey]] | founded = 1959 | folded = 2012 | teams = | tv = | country = {{AUT}} 
{{HUN}}  | champion = [[HC TWK Innsbruck]] | most_champs = [[EHC Lustenau]] (7) | ceo = | website = }} The '''Austrian National League''' ({{lang-de|Österreichische Eishockey-Nationalliga}}) is a former second tier ice hockey league in [[Ice hockey in Austria|Austria]]. For the [[2012–13 Inter-National League season|2012–13]] season, it was replaced by the [[Inter-National League]]. ==Decline== With the conclusion of the [[2011–12 Austrian National League season|2011–12]] season, seven of the twelve teams left the league. Two teams, [[Dornbirner EC|Dornbirner]] and [[HC TWK Innsbruck|TWK Innsbruck]] were invited to join the [[Austrian Hockey League]] {{cite web |url=http://www.iihf.com/home-of-hockey/news/news-singleview/recap/7176.html?tx_ttnews%5BbackPid%5D=955&cHash=c4f36f608e |title=New Austro-Slovenian league: Inter-National-League to start one tier below EBEL |author=Martin Merk |language= |publisher=IIHF.com |date=July 14, 2012 |accessdate=September 6, 2012 }}{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} The farm teams of the [[Vienna Capitals]], [[EC KAC]] and the [[EHC Black Wings Linz]] all withdrew to join a junior Austrian Hockey League. This proved to be the end of the National League. Four of the remaining teams - [[EK Zell am See]], [[EHC Bregenzerwald]], [[VEU Feldkirch]] and [[EHC Lustenau]] - all subsequently joined the [[Inter-National League]]. ==Champions== {| class="wikitable" |- ! {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2014}} {{Infobox non Test cricket team | name = Bahrain | image = Flag of Bahrain.svg | image_size = | caption = | nickname = | association = [[Bahrain Cricket Association]] | icc_status = [[ICC members|Associate member]]{{cite web|url=https://www.icc-cricket.com/news/422449|title=Ireland and Afghanistan ICC newest full members amid wide-ranging governance reform|work=[[International Cricket Council]]|date=22 June 2017|accessdate=1 September 2018}} | icc_member_year = 2017 | icc_region = [[Asian Cricket Council|Asia]] | WCL_division = n/a (regional tournaments) | coach = | captain = | first_match = {{flagicon|Bahrain|1972}} '''Bahrain''' v. {{cr-rt|Kuwait}}
([[Kuwait City]]; 30 October 1979) | first_fc = | first_la = | first_t20 = | asofdate = 4 September 2015 }} The '''Bahrain national cricket team''' is the team that represents the country of [[Bahrain]] in [[international cricket]]. The team is organised by the [[Bahrain Cricket Association]] (BCA), which became an [[International Cricket Council|ICC]] affiliate member in 2001{{cite web|url=http://www.cricketarchive.co.uk/Archive/Countries/37.html|title=The Home of CricketArchive|work=cricketarchive.co.uk}} and an [[ICC members|associate member]] in 2017. The Bahraini national side made its first international appearance in 1979, at a tournament with [[Kuwait national cricket team|Kuwait]], [[Qatar national cricket team|Qatar]], and Sharjah (one of the [[United Arab Emirates national cricket team|United Arab Emirates]]). Its first appearance in an [[Asian Cricket Council]] tournament came at the [[2004 ACC Trophy]] in Malaysia; since then, Bahrain has regularly appeared in ACC events. Bahrain has also made several appearances in [[World Cricket League]] tournaments, but was relegated back to regional tournaments after finishing fifth at the [[2013 ICC World Cricket League Division Six|2013 Division Six]] event.[https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Teams/2/2381/Other_Matches.html Other matches played by Bahrain] – CricketArchive. Retrieved 4 September 2015. In April 2018, the ICC decided to grant full [[Twenty20 International]] (T20I) status to all its members. Therefore, all [[Twenty20]] matches played between Bahrain and other [[List of International Cricket Council members|ICC members]] after 1 January 2019 will be a full T20I.{{cite web|url=https://www.icc-cricket.com/media-releases/672322|title=All T20 matches between ICC members to get international status|publisher=[[International Cricket Council]]|date=26 April '''Chinese Cricket Association''' is the official [[Sport governing body|governing body]] of the sport of [[cricket]] in [[China]]. Its current headquarters are at [[Beijing]], [[China]]. The Chinese Cricket Association is China's representative in the [[International Cricket Council]] (ICC), of which it has been an affiliate member since 2004. It is also a member of the [[Asian Cricket Council]].<ref>[https://archive.is/20130123071103/http://www.forbes.com/2005/09/30/china-india-cricket_cx_pm_1003chinacricket.html China's Cracking Cricket], Forbes.com (October 3, 2005). Retrieved 2012-0130.</ref><ref name="cricinfo06"> [http://www.espncricinfo.com/ci/content/story/245632.html Cricket development in China] ESPNCricinfo (May 2006). Retrieved 27 January 2012</ref>
In 2006, the Chinese Cricket Association outlined its goals as:-<ref name="cricinfo06" /> *2015: Have 20,000 players and 2,000 coaches *2019: Qualify for the World Cup *2020: Gain Test status
The talent pool in China has been improving, and in the national cricket championships of 2011, 48 schools took part, 21 more than the previous year.<ref>[http://blogs.espncricinfo.com/btw/archives/2011/08/big_turnout_for.php Big turnout for Chinese national championship] ESPNCricinfo - Beyond The Test World Blog. Retrieved 27 January 2012</ref> Cricket's growing popularity was underlined by the fact when the north-eastern city of [[Daqing]] and the north-eastern province of [[Heilongjiang]] became the ninth province in China to take to cricket, although they were part of a snowy and wintry atmosphere, and playing cricket there was not easy.<ref> [http://blogs.espncricinfo.com/btw/archives/2011/11/daqing_makes_a.php Daqing makes a dash] ESPNCricinfo - Beyond the Test World Blog. Retrieved 27 January 2012</ref> In 2015, the Chinese Women’s team played in Group B of the [[2015 ICC Women's World Twenty20 Qualifier]], however did not progress through to the [[2016 ICC Women's World Twenty20]].<ref name="ICC-April16">{{cite web|url=http://www.icc-cricket.com/news/2016/media-releases/94751/outcomes-from-icc-board-and-committee-meetings|title=Outcomes from ICC Board and committee meetings|work=International Cricket Council|date=25 April 2016|accessdate=2 July 2016}}</ref>
The ICC reported approximately 45,000 male players and 35,000 female players in China by April 2016, and is to work with the CCA to develop long term development strategy.<ref name="ICC-April16" />
==See also== *[[China national cricket team|China men's national cricket team]] *[[China women's national cricket team]] *[[Asian Cricket Council]]

{{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} {{Infobox football club | clubname = Coast Stars| image = Coast Stars.png| image_size = 100| alt = Logo| fullname = Coast Stars| nickname = | founded = 1998| ground = [[Mombasa Municipal Stadium]]
[[Mombasa]], [[Kenya]] | capacity = 10,000| chairman = | manager = | league = | season = 2006/07 | position = | | pattern_la1=|pattern_b1=_vneckwhite|pattern_ra1=|leftarm1=FFFFFF|body1=33A1DE|rightarm1=FFFFFF|shorts1=33A1DE|socks1=33A1DE| }} '''Coast Stars''' is a [[Kenya]]n [[football (soccer)|football]] club based in [[Mombasa]]. The club was founded in 1998. They are a member of the top division in Kenyan football. Their home stadium is [[Mombasa Municipal Stadium]]. They played the 2004/05 season under the name Dubai Bank Limited Club after their sponsors [[Dubai Bank]]. The original name was reverted to in the next season. One of the players that has moved to Europe from Coast Stars is [[Emmanuel Ake]]. ==Performance in CAF competitions== *'''[[CAF Cup Winners' Cup]]''': 1 appearance ::2000 – First Round {{Kenyan Premier League plain}} [[Category:Football clubs in Kenya]] [[Category:Association football clubs established in 1998]] [[Category:Sport in Mombasa]] [[Category:1998 establishments in Kenya]] {{Kenya-footyclub-stub}}

{{Doping in sport sidebar |expanded=History}} Some racing drivers have used '''doping in auto racing''' to enhance their performance. Deemed unsafe and illegal by the [[Fédération Internationale de l'Automobile]]. Appendix A to the [[International Sporting Code]] determines which substances are banned and mandates penalties.
==Appendix A to the International Sporting Code== The Appendix regarding doping in auto racing was added on 1 December 2010 after consultation with the [[World Anti-Doping Agency]] (WADA). The regulations apply to all FIA and national sanctioned events. The FIA adopts the banned substance list issued by WADA. The FIA has added [[alcohol (drug)|alcohol]] and [[beta blockers]] to the list.<ref>{{cite web|title=PROHIBITED IN PARTICULAR SPORTS|url=https://www.wada-ama.org/en/prohibited-list/prohibited-in-particular-sports/beta-blockers|website=WADA|accessdate=10 September 2017}}</ref> The FIA will test at random from a pre determined pool of drivers. The national sanctioning body will test a number of athletes during their events.
In case of a positive doping test, the driver in question will be disqualified, have his/hers results forfeited and has to return all their winnings. In case of negligence by the driver will only be disqualified for the event on hand. In case of a second violation the driver will be banned from the sport for six months. More severe penalties could be imposed, depending on the circumstances. The driver has to pay back price money won. A fine of up to € 15.000 can be imposed.<ref>{{cite web|title=Appendix A - FIA Anti-Doping Regulations - 2017|url=http://www.fia.com/file/51922/download/12835?token=imYs-6AK|website=FIA|accessdate=10 September 2017}}</ref>
==INDYCAR== Since the series inception in [[1996 Indy Racing League|1996]], [[INDYCAR]] has a substance abuse policy in place. The policy is applied to all series sanctioned by INDYCAR, currently the [[IndyCar Series]], [[Indy Lights]], [[Pro Mazda]], [[USF2000]] and [[Global MX-5 Cup]]. Drivers, crew and officials can be subjected to testing (depending on the series). The INDYCAR organisation can subject subjects to test at random. INDYCAR may require a drug test also in events of 'reasonable suspicion'. Reasonable suspicion includes, but is not limited to, violent temper or an accident during the event. When a driver is tested positive for [[performance enhancing drugs]] (PED) the driver will be suspended for one year. A fine of $ 5.000 wil also be imposed. With a non-PED positive test (alcohol for example) the driver will be suspended for no less than sixty days. A fine of $ 2.500 wil also be imposed.
In the case of multiple violations the driver will be penalized again. The height of the penalty will be determined by the specific circumstances. The driver may return to competition after psychological and medical evaluation.<ref>{{cite web|title=2017 INDYCAR Substance Abuse Policy|url=https://hardcards.indycar.com/Resources/pdfs/2017/2017_INDYCAR_Substance_Abuse_Policy.pdf|website=INDYCAR|accessdate=14 September 2017}}</ref>
==NASCAR== [[File:TSM AJ Allmendinger - 2015 - Stierch 3.jpg|thumb|left|A.J. Allmendinger]] [[NASCAR]] has its own anti doping regulations. The substance abuse policy was first implemented in the late 1980s. Flaws in the systems allowed drivers to continue to use banned substances. One notorious case was that of [[Aaron Fike]]. After being arrested for [[heroin]] possession, Fike admitted using [[black tar heroin]] during race weekends.<ref>{{cite web|title=Former truck racer Fike admits using heroin on race days|url=http://www.espn.com/racing/nascar/truck/news/story?id=3336865|website=ESPN.com|accessdate=10 September 2017}}</ref> In [[2009 NASCAR Sprint Cup Series|2009]], [[Jeremy Mayfield]] failed a drug test for [[methamphetamine]] with his stepmother declaring Mayfield has used meth as early as 1998. After sitting out the initial penalty, Mayfield tested positive again.<ref>{{cite web|title=NASCAR driver Mayfield fails another drug test|url=https://pilotonline.com/sports/auto-racing/nascar-driver-mayfield-fails-another-drug-test/article_b96c0760-dd15-563a-90a1-ed66805966ec.html|website=The Virginian Pilot|accessdate=14 September 2017}}</ref> Mayfield could return to NASCAR competition after completing the Road to Recovery. The driver however has questioned the credibility of the testing laboratory recognized by NASCAR.<ref>{{cite web|title=Jeremy Mayfield adamant he didn't use drugs, won't go through NASCAR recovery program|url=http://www.sportingnews.com/nascar/news/jeremy-mayfield-video-drug-suspension-nascar-lawsuit-recovery-program-meth-stolen-property/2zqljx2u39ia1i97fz2qpk4x8|website=Sporting News|accessdate=14 September 2017}}</ref>
Following the case of Fike and the case of Mayfield, the policy was overhauled. [[A.J. Allmendinger]] was one of the first big name drivers failing a drug test. Allmendinger tested positive for [[Adderall]]. Allmendinger was suspended, fired by team owner [[Roger Penske]], and returned to competition 2,5 months.<ref>{{cite web|title=NASCAR: The Curious Case of AJ Allmendinger|url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/1362398-nascar-the-curious-case-of-aj-allmendinger|website=Bleacher Report|accessdate=10 September 2017}}</ref> Because of the nature of the NASCAR garage, drivers and crew members can be tested by the organisation, especially because performance enhancing drugs can be abused by crew members. Crew chief [[Todd Parrott]], for driver [[Aric Almirola]], tested positive for an 'undisclosed substance'. The NASCAR policy is consistent with the FIA's policy.<ref>{{cite web|title=Previously suspended crew chief has completed NASCAR Road to Recovery program|url=http://www.nascar.com/en_us/news-media/articles/2014/1/7/todd-parrott-reinstated-nascar-road-to-recovery.html|website=NASCAR|accessdate=10 September 2017}}</ref>
In 2018 28-year old [[Spencer Gallagher]] won his first [[2018 NASCAR Xfinity Series|NASCAR Xfinity Series]] race on 28th of April. On May 1st Gallagher failed the drug test. Gallagher was suspended indefinitely and agreed to join the Road to Recovery program.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nascar.com/news-media/2018/05/02/spencer-gallagher-issued-substance-abuse-policy-penalty-nascar/|title=Gallagher issued Substance Abuse Policy penalty|last=|first=|date=|website=NASCAR|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>n
After testing positive for a banned substance, the person in question is suspended indefinitely. To return to competition the person needs to complete the NASCAR Road to Recovery and have a Road to Recovery Plan approved. The plan includes treatment, rehabilitation, counseling and other measures necessary to prevent repetition.<ref>{{cite web|title=ALLMENDINGER TO PARTICIPATE IN RECOVERY PROGRAM|url=http://www.nascar.com/en_us/news-media/articles/2012/07/25/aallmendinger-recovery-program.html|website=NASCAR|accessdate=10 September 2017}}</ref>
==USAC== The [[United States Auto Club]] has implemented a substance abuse policy since 2008.<ref>{{cite web|title=USAC CONTINUES MOTORSPORTS LEADERSHIP ROLE WITH SUBSTANCE ABUSE POLICY ANNOUNCEMENT|url=http://www.usacracing.com/content/view/7281/1/|website=USAC|accessdate=11 September 2017|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080213185622/http://www.usacracing.com/content/view/7281/1/|archivedate=13 February 2008|df=}}</ref> USAC also has a self determined list of banned substances, with the exclusion of prescription medication (used in accordance with the purpose and instruction). The policy states that USAC has to have reasonable suspicion that banned substances are used. The policy states (but is not limited to) a list of symptoms for drug and/or alcohol use. USAC also has the right to test at random. With a positive drug or alcohol test the USAC Director of Competition may suspend the driver indefinitely. After the failure of a drug test, the driver can return to competition after a negative drug test after the suspension period. After a failed alcohol test, the driver only has to sit out the suspended period. In both cases the driver will be subjected to more frequent tests in the future.<ref>{{cite web|title=2008 Substance Abuse Policy|url=http://www.usacracing.com/assets/files/allseries/forms/substanceabusepolicy.pdf|website=USAC|accessdate=11 September 2017}}</ref>
==World Racing Group== {| class="wikitable" align=right |- ! # !! Fine !! Banned from competition |- !align=left| First offense | $ 1.000 | 60-90 days |- !align=left| Second offense | $ 2.500 | 120-180 days |- !align=left| Third offense | $ 5.000 | 365 days |} The [[World Racing Group]], sanctioning body of the [[World of Outlaws]] and [[Super DIRTcar Series|DIRTcar]] series, started regularly testing the [[Sprint car racing|sprint car]] and [[World of Outlaws Late Model Series|late model]] series drivers in 2017.<ref>{{cite web|title=Drug Testing For World Of Outlaws Drivers Testing begins in 2017 for sprint car and late model drivers|url=http://racingroundup.com/drug-testing-for-world-of-outlaws-drivers-testing-begins-in-2017-for-sprint-car-and-late-model-drivers-by-speed-sport-staff-december-8-2016/|website=Racing Roundup|accessdate=14 September 2017}}</ref> Drivers will only be tested through [[urinalysis]]. The random selection process will take place on the day of the event, treating full season drivers and parttime drivers equally.<ref>{{cite web|title=Frequently Asked Questions about Drug Testing|url=http://woosprint.com/images/stories/MainImages/PDF/DFSFAQS.pdf|website=World of Outlaws|accessdate=14 September 2017}}</ref> After a positive test, the driver receives a fine and will be banned from competition. After three failed tests (and three penalties) the driver can only return to competition after two negative tests and approval from World Racing Group.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eldoraspeedway.com/forms/wrg-substance-abuse.pdf|title=SUBSTANCE ABUSE POLICY TERMS AND CONDITIONS|last=|first=|date=|website=Eldora Speedway|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=14 September 2017}}</ref>
[[Justin Ratliff]] was the first driver hit with a penalty. Ratliff refused a drug test after the [[World of Outlaws Late Model Series|2017]] DIRTcar Nationals at [[Volusia Speedway Park]] in February. Because of the refusal Ratliff was fined in accordance of the first offense with a 90 day suspension.<ref>{{cite web|title=JUSTIN RATLIFF REFUSED WORLD OF OUTLAWS DRUG TEST – DRIVER SUSPENDED|url=https://racingnews.co/2017/04/19/justin-ratliff-world-of-outlaws-drug-test/|website=Racing News|accessdate=14 September 2017}}</ref> In June 2017, [[Brian Lay]] tested positive after the World of Outlaws event at [[Eldora Speedway]]. He was also fined in accordance with a first offense.<ref>{{cite web|title=Brian Lay fails to complete World of Outlaws drug test and is hit with first offense penalty|url=https://sprintcarunlimited.com/brian-lay-fails-complete-world-outlaws-drug-test-hit-first-offense-penalty-donny-schatz-fined-lawrenceburg-incident/|website=Sprintcar Unlimited|accessdate=14 September 2017}}</ref> In July [[Jacob Hawkins]] failed a drug test after the [[Eldora Speedway#The Dirt Late Model Dream|Dirt Late Model Dream]] event at Eldora Speedway.<ref>{{cite web|title=DIRTCAR RACING DRIVER FAILED DIRT LATE MODEL DREAM DRUG TEST|url=https://racingnews.co/2017/07/01/dirtcar-racing-driver-failed-dirt-late-model-dream-drug-test/|website=Racing News|accessdate=14 September 2017}}</ref>
==IMCA== The [[International Motor Contest Association]], the oldest active motorsports sanctioning body in the United States, has regulations with regard to drugs and alcohol. The 2017 IMCA General Rules and Procedures state the following with regard to drugs and alcohol: ''Consumption of alcoholic beverage by driver or his/her crew in advance of, or while competing in any IMCA sanctioned program is strictly forbidden. Any driver showing evidence of alcohol consumption will be required to leave the premises immediately and may be subject to a fine of no less than $250. Use of illegal drugs at any time shall be cause for immediate, indefinite suspension and/or fine of no less than $250.''<ref>{{cite web|title=2017 General Rules|url=https://www.imca.com/rules/general/|website=IMCA|accessdate=11 September 2017}}</ref>
==Notable cases==
===Tomáš Enge=== [[File:Profil tomas.jpg|thumb|right|Tomáš Enge]] {{also|Tomáš Enge}} During the [[2002 International Formula 3000 Championship]] Czech racer Tomáš Enge tested positive after the race at the [[Hungaroring]]. Enge raced the remaining rounds of the championship while there was an investigation. The Czech driver went on to win the championship, however the FIA determined in October that the test was positive and Enge was disqualified from the Hungaroring round. Enge dropped to third in the championship standings and [[Sebastien Bourdais]] was the official champion.<ref>{{cite web|title=Tomas Enge loses F3000 title|url=http://www.gpupdate.net/en/f1-news/39094/tomas-enge-loses-f3000-title/|website=GP Update|accessdate=10 September 2017}}</ref> In 2012 Enge again tested positive for a banned substance. After the [[2012 FIA GT1 Navarra round]] Enge tested positive, him claiming it was a drug for medical purposes. The FIA banned Enge from motorsports for 18 months.<ref>{{cite web|title=Enge given 18-month ban for failing drugs test|url=http://m.gpupdate.net/en/f1-news/282368/enge-given-18-month-ban-for-failing-drugs-test/|website=GP Update|accessdate=10 September 2017}}</ref> He returned to competition in [[2014 Blancpain Endurance Series|2014]] racing in the [[Blancpain Endurance Series]].
===Franck Montagny=== {{also|Franck Montagny}} Montagny tested positive for a [[cocaine]] derivative ([[Benzoylecgonine]]) after the [[2014 Putrajaya ePrix]]. Montagny was disqualified from the race but kept his championship points and podium finish from the [[2014 Beijing ePrix|previous race]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.autosport.com/fe/news/117253/montagny-tests-positive-for-drug-use|title=Ex-F1 driver Franck Montangy tests positive for cocaine derivative|last=|first=|date=|website=autosport.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=10 September 2017}}</ref> The 37-year old was banned from motorsport for two years after a second test also proved positive. The Frenchman publicly feared that the ban would be the effective end to his racing career. His ban was lifted on December 23, 2016 but he has not competed since.<ref>{{cite web|title=Ex-F1 driver Franck Montagny gets two-year ban over doping test|url=https://www.autosport.com/fe/news/118272/montagny-gets-twoyear-racing-ban|website=Autosport|accessdate=10 September 2017}}</ref>
===Raphael Matos=== {{also|Raphael Matos}} In 2015 Brazilian former [[IndyCar Series]] driver [[Raphael Matos]] failed a drug test. Matos competed in the [[2015 Stock Car Brasil season]]. After the October round at [[Autódromo Internacional de Curitiba|Curitiba]] Matos tested positive for a banned substance. The Brazilian Automobile Confederation suspended his licence for two years.<ref>{{cite web|title=Former IndyCar driver Matos gets two-year ban for doping|url=https://www.motorsport.com/stockcar-br/news/former-indycar-driver-matos-gets-two-year-ban-for-doping/|website=Motorsport.com|accessdate=14 September 2017}}</ref> Matos returned to competition in the [[Trans-Am Series]]. Matos made his debut in the [[2017 Trans-Am Series|2017]] [[Detroit Grand Prix (IndyCar)|Motor City 100]] finishing second in the TA2 class.<ref>{{cite web|title=Trans Am ready for Motor City alongside 3-Dimensional Services|url=http://gotransam.com/news/Trans-Am-ready-for-Motor-City-alongside-3-Dimensional-Services/66714|website=Trans-Am|accessdate=14 September 2017}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Doping in sport]] [[Category:Cheating]] [[Category:Fédération Internationale de l'Automobile]] [[Category:NASCAR]] [[Category:Indy Racing League]]

{{infobox venue | name = Elverum Stadion | nickname = Sentralidrettsplassen | image = File:Elverum Stadion.jpg | fullname = | former_names = Sentralidrettsplassen | location = [[Elverum]], [[Norway]] | coordinates = {{coord|60.8879791|11.5547995|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = | built = 1950 | opened = | renovated = 2006 (Artificial Turf)
2013 (Renovated) | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = | operator = | surface = [[Artificial turf]] | scoreboard = | estimated_cost = | suites = | architect = | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | capacity = 1,400 {{cite web|author=Marthe Stenberg |url=http://www.ostlendingen.no/sport/elverum-fotball/elverum-fotball/far-kun-plass-til-1-400/s/2-2.2757-1.7818856 |title=Østlendingen - Får kun plass til 1.400 |website=Ostlendingen.no |date= |accessdate=2016-09-26}} | record_attendance = 4,633 {{cite web|url=http://kxweb.no/portal/theme/organization/news/show.do?id=9242356 |title=Elverum Fotball |website=Kxweb.no |date=2013-03-22 |accessdate=2016-09-26}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nifs.no/kampfakta.php?kamp_id=16270&land=1&t=6&u=140&lag1=161&lag2=50 |title=NIFS - Norsk & Internasjonal Fotballstatistikk |website=Nifs.no |date=1991-09-01 |accessdate=2016-09-26}} | executive_suites = | dimensions = 110 m x 67 m{{cite web|title=Elverum Stadion|url=https://www.fotball.no/fotballdata/anlegg/hjem/?fiksId=6963|website=fotball.no|publisher=[[Norwegian Football Association]]|accessdate=25 September 2016}} | acreage = | tenants = [[Elverum Fotball]] (football) | }} '''Elverum Stadion''', also known as '''Sentralidrettsplassen''' is a football stadium located in [[Elverum]], [[Norway]]. It is the home ground of [[Elverum Fotball]] in the [[2. Divisjon]]. Elverum Stadion acquired [[Artificial Turf]] in 2006. They had new artificial turf put in and further renovated the stadium in 2013 ahead of the [[2013 Norwegian First Division|2013 season]] where Elverum made their comeback at the second tier of Norwegian football after a 17-year absence. After the renovation the capacity of Elverum Stadion is 1,400. The record attendace at Elverum Stadion is 4,633. The record was set when Elverum played rivals [[Ham-Kam]] 1 September 1991. Ham-Kam won the game 3-0. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category|Elverum stadion}} *[http://kxweb.no/portal/public/showContentCategory.do?id=5731 Official website] {{DEFAULTSORT:Elverum Stadion}} [[Category:Football venues in Norway]] [[Category:Bandy venues in Norway]] [[Category:Sports venues in Hedmark]] [[Category:Elverum]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1950]] [[Category:1950 establishments in Norway]] {{Norway-sports-venue-stub}}
